Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I gripped the steering wheel as rain streaked across my windshield, wipers working overtime. As a taxi driver, I knew I had to drive defensively, especially with cars darting between lanes and brake lights flaring unpredictably. My job demanded vigilance—one mistake could mean an accident, a ticket, or worse. But as a citizen, I felt the weight of other responsibilities pressing in. My tax documents were finally in order, and I’d promised myself I’d help at the free vaccine clinic this weekend, just like last year. The community needed volunteers, and I wanted to do my part. But the rain meant longer hours on the road, more anxious passengers, and less time for anything else. I could feel the tension building inside me—should I focus on my job, keeping every ride safe and legal, or should I carve out time to serve my community, even if it meant less rest and more stress? The demands of both roles pulled at me, and I wasn’t sure which expectation I could afford to let down.
